She also reports increased fatigue and sluggishness but minimizes these symptoms when describing them. Fatigue may relate to protein loss and overall systemic illness. Common in young adults.  2. Diagnosis: Heart failure (e.g., early congestive heart failure) Justification: Bilateral pedal and facial edema, along with systemic symptoms, suggest possible cardiac dysfunction. Fatigue aligns with reduced cardiac output.  3. Diagnosis: Hypothyroidism Justification: Fatigue and sluggishness are classic; generalized or peripheral edema (myxedema) can cause facial and peripheral swelling in hypothyroidism.  4. Diagnosis: Liver cirrhosis with ascites and edema Justification: Edema can be part of low albumin states in liver disease; though less common at this age without history, still a differential in systemic edema.  5. Diagnosis: Allergic or inflammatory edema Justification: Allergic angioedema or inflammation could cause facial swelling; however, ankle/foot swelling less typical unless related to systemic allergic response.  6. Diagnosis: Renal failure (acute or chronic) Justification: Increased fatigue, edema, and systemic symptoms could indicate impaired renal function leading to volume overload.  7. Diagnosis: Cushing’s syndrome Justification: Fatigue and edema might be present; however, other features like central obesity and skin changes usually noted.  8. Diagnosis: Protein-losing enteropathy Justification: Rare but can cause systemic edema with hypoalbuminemia, presenting similarly.  9. Diagnosis: Vasculitis Justification: Systemic vasculitis can cause edema and fatigue; skin changes would need closer examination, but possible.  10. Diagnosis: Deep venous thrombosis with post-thrombotic syndrome Justification: Usually unilateral swelling; bilateral edema less likely, so least likely here. The two-week progression is consistent with subclinical or overt hypothyroidism developing gradually. The sluggishness reported also supports this. The minimal symptoms reported may underrepresent systemic activity.
